key_points: Buckingham Palace issued its first statement since the interview, expressing sadness and concern, especially regarding race issues.
The statement acknowledges differences in recollections but takes the issues raised in the interview very seriously.
The statement reaffirms Harry, Meghan, and Archie's status as loved family members.
The interview revealed conversations about the skin color of Harry and Meghan's baby and did not involve Queen Elizabeth or Prince Philip.
Meghan discussed rifts within the family, including changes to royal protocols affecting their son, Archie, and a reversal of a reported incident involving Catherine.
Harry expressed disappointment in his father and distanced himself from his brother William, citing 'different paths'.
A crisis for the British monarchy has been acknowledged by royal correspondents, with the interview raising more questions than answers.
The interview is divisive among Britons, with younger people showing support for Harry and Meghan, while older generations support the monarchy.
Harry and Meghan offered a nuanced view of their relationship with Queen Elizabeth, despite issues with 'the firm'.
Prince Charles was shown engaging in public health efforts, highlighting his work during the interview's fallout.
spokespersons: Roya Nikkhah (Royal Correspondent, The Sunday Times)
